ben.ladalja

Class QueryBuilder<T extends QueryBuilder>

  • java.lang.Object
    • ben.ladalja.QueryBuilder<T>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    QueryBuilderORM

    public class QueryBuilder<T extends QueryBuilder>
extends java.lang.Object
    Ladalja's database query builder provides a convenient, fluent interface to creating and running database queries.
    It can be used to perform most database operations in your application and works on all supported database systems.

    The Ladalja query builder uses prepared query to protect your application against SQL injection attacks.
    There is no need to clean strings being passed as bindings.

    There are some using examples : 

     ResultSet result = DB.table("users").get(); //select * from users
 
 ResultSet result = DB.table("users").where("email","example@example.com").first(); //select * from users where email=? limit 1;
 if(result.next()){
     result.getString("password");
 ...
 

 Map<String,Object> map = new HashMap<>()
 map.put("email","example@example.com");
 map.put("nom","Example");
 int tabAge[] = {19,20,23};
 
 DB.table("users").insert(map); //insert into users (email,nom) values(?,?);
 DB.table("users").whereIn("age",tabAge).update(map); //update users set email=?, nom=? where age in (?,?,?); 
 ...

    And more complicated query.

    Author:
    MEZATSONG TSAFACK Carrel, meztsacar@gmail.com

        public void update(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> arg)

        Parameters:

        public void delete()
        Delete records from the table via the delete method. You may constrain delete statements by adding where clauses before calling the delete method

      • increment

        public void increment(java.lang.String column)
        Method for incrementing the value of a given column. This is simply a shortcut, providing a more expressive and terse interface compared to manually writing the update statement. This methods accept only one argument: the column to modify. the amount by which the column will be incremented is 1
        Parameters:
        column -

      • increment

        public void increment(java.lang.String column,
                      int supplement)
        Method for incrementing the value of a given column. This is simply a shortcut, providing a more expressive and terse interface compared to manually writing the update statement. This methods accept at least one argument: the column to modify. A second argument passed to control the amount by which the column should be incremented
        Parameters:
        column -
        supplement - the amount by which the column should be incremented

      • decrement

        public void decrement(java.lang.String column)
        Method for decrementing the value of a given column. This is simply a shortcut, providing a more expressive and terse interface compared to manually writing the update statement. This methods accept one argument: the column to modify. The amount by which the column will be decremented is 1
        Parameters:
        column -

      • decrement

        public void decrement(java.lang.String column,
                      int reduction)
        Method for decrementing the value of a given column. This is simply a shortcut, providing a more expressive and terse interface compared to manually writing the update statement. This methods accept two arguments, one: the column to modify. A second argument passed to control the amount by which the column should be decremented
        Parameters:
        column -
        reduction - the amount by which the column should be decremented

      • where

        public T where(java.lang.String column,
               java.lang.String operator,
               java.lang.Object value)
        You may use the where method on a query builder instance to add where clauses to the query. The most basic call to where requires three arguments. The first argument is the name of the column. The second argument is an operator, which can be any of the database's supported operators. Finally, the third argument is the value to evaluate against the column.
        Parameters:
        column -
        operator -
        value -
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

                 java.lang.String order)
        The orderBy method allows you to sort the result of the query by a given column. The first argument to the orderBy method should be the column you wish to sort by, while the second argument controls the direction of the sort and may be either asc or desc
        Parameters:
        column -
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

        public T orderByDesc(java.lang.String column)
        Sort the result of the query by a given column in descending order.
        Parameters:
        column -
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

      • sharedLock

        public T sharedLock()
        The query builder also includes a few functions to help you do "pessimistic locking" on your select statements. To run the statement with a "shared lock", you may use the sharedLock method on a query. A shared lock prevents the selected rows from being modified until your transaction commits
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

      • lockForUpdate

        public T lockForUpdate()
        sharedLock alternative for using the "for update" lock. A "for update" lock prevents the rows from being modified or from being selected with another shared lock
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

      • join

        public T join(java.lang.String joinTable,
              java.lang.String column,
              java.lang.String operator,
              java.lang.String joinColumn)
        The query builder may also be used to write join statements. To perform a basic "inner join", you may use the join method on a query builder instance. The first argument passed to the join method is the name of the table you need to join to, while the remaining arguments specify the column constraints for the join. Of course, you can join at most two tables in a single query
        Parameters:
        joinTable -
        column -
        operator -
        joinColumn -
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

      • leftJoin

        public T leftJoin(java.lang.String joinTable,
                  java.lang.String column,
                  java.lang.String operator,
                  java.lang.String joinColumn)
        If you would like to perform a "left join" instead of an "inner join", use the leftJoin method. The leftJoin method has the same signature as the join method
        Parameters:
        joinTable -
        column -
        operator -
        joinColumn -
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

      • crossJoin

        public T crossJoin(java.lang.String joinTable)
        To perform a "cross join" use the crossJoin method with the name of the table you wish to cross join to. Cross joins generate a cartesian product between the first table and the joined table
        Parameters:
        joinTable -
        Returns:
        this object with new changes

        The query builder also provides a quick way to "union" two queries together. For example, you may create an initial query and use the union method to union it with a second query
